title: Some optical illusions
description: Generating some optical illusions. Code courtesy of Andy Blance @ UNSW MED CBDRH.
contents:
Which center box is lighter?


# Constructing some optical illusions.
grid.newpage()

grid.rect(c(1,3,1,3)/4, c(3,3,1,1)/4, 1/2, 1/2, gp = gpar(col = NA, fill = gray(1:4/5)))

grid.rect(c(1,3,1,3)/4, c(3,3,1,1)/4, 1/6, 1/6, gp = gpar(col = NA, fill = gray(0.5)))




Centre boxes look different depending on background


grid.newpage()

grid.rect(c(1,3,1,3)/4, c(3,3,1,1)/4, 1/2, 1/2, gp = gpar(col = NA, fill = c("green", "red")))

grid.rect(c(1,3,1,3)/4, c(3,3,1,1)/4, 1/6, 1/6, gp = gpar(col = NA, fill = c("blue", "blue","yellow", "yellow")))




Reverse of the above


grid.newpage()

grid.rect(c(1,3,1,3)/4, c(3,3,1,1)/4, 1/2, 1/2, gp = gpar(col = NA, fill = c("yellow", "blue")))

grid.rect(c(1,3,1,3)/4, c(3,3,1,1)/4, 1/6, 1/6, gp = gpar(col = NA, fill = c("red", "red","green", "green")))




Are the grey lines horizontal or slanted?


grid.newpage()

rs <- expand.grid(x = seq(0, 1, 1/10), y = seq(0, 1, 1/10))

grid.rect(rs$x, rs$y, 1/10/2, 1/10/2, gp = gpar(fill = "black", col = NA))

grid.rect(rs$x + 1/10/4, rs$y + 1/10/2, 1/10/2, 1/10/2, gp = gpar(fill = "black", col = NA))

ls <- expand.grid(x = 0:1, y = seq(0, 1, 1/20) - 1/20/2)

grid.polyline(ls$x, ls$y, id = gl(nrow(ls)/2, 2), gp = gpar(col = "grey50", lwd = 1))




Working through the R code you can see how each of these images is constructed.
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing, native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

title: DataViz Exercises
description: Working through the week 3 interactive/tutorial of HDAT9800
contents:
We are following some example work from https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html
Because of time Iâ€™m not going to recreate much of the text from that chapter.

# A tibble: 6 x 11
  manufacturer model displ  year   cyl trans   drv     cty   hwy fl   
  <chr>        <chr> <dbl> <int> <int> <chr>   <chr> <int> <int> <chr>
1 audi         a4      1.8  1999     4 auto(l~ f        18    29 p    
2 audi         a4      1.8  1999     4 manual~ f        21    29 p    
3 audi         a4      2    2008     4 manual~ f        20    31 p    
4 audi         a4      2    2008     4 auto(a~ f        21    30 p    
5 audi         a4      2.8  1999     6 auto(l~ f        16    26 p    
6 audi         a4      2.8  1999     6 manual~ f        18    26 p    
# ... with 1 more variable: class <chr>




Some ways to check dimensions / check out the dataset

[1] 234
[1] 11
tibble [234 x 11] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame)
 $ manufacturer: chr [1:234] "audi" "audi" "audi" "audi" ...
 $ model       : chr [1:234] "a4" "a4" "a4" "a4" ...
 $ displ       : num [1:234] 1.8 1.8 2 2 2.8 2.8 3.1 1.8 1.8 2 ...
 $ year        : int [1:234] 1999 1999 2008 2008 1999 1999 2008 1999 1999 2008 ...
 $ cyl         : int [1:234] 4 4 4 4 6 6 6 4 4 4 ...
 $ trans       : chr [1:234] "auto(l5)" "manual(m5)" "manual(m6)" "auto(av)" ...
 $ drv         : chr [1:234] "f" "f" "f" "f" ...
 $ cty         : int [1:234] 18 21 20 21 16 18 18 18 16 20 ...
 $ hwy         : int [1:234] 29 29 31 30 26 26 27 26 25 28 ...
 $ fl          : chr [1:234] "p" "p" "p" "p" ...
 $ class       : chr [1:234] "compact" "compact" "compact" "compact" ...
[1] 234  11
Rows: 234
Columns: 11
$ manufacturer <chr> "audi", "audi", "audi", "audi", "audi", "audi",~
$ model        <chr> "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4", "a4 q~
$ displ        <dbl> 1.8, 1.8, 2.0, 2.0, 2.8, 2.8, 3.1, 1.8, 1.8, 2.~
$ year         <int> 1999, 1999, 2008, 2008, 1999, 1999, 2008, 1999,~
$ cyl          <int> 4, 4, 4, 4, 6, 6, 6, 4, 4, 4, 4, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6,~
$ trans        <chr> "auto(l5)", "manual(m5)", "manual(m6)", "auto(a~
$ drv          <chr> "f", "f", "f", "f", "f", "f", "f", "4", "4", "4~
$ cty          <int> 18, 21, 20, 21, 16, 18, 18, 18, 16, 20, 19, 15,~
$ hwy          <int> 29, 29, 31, 30, 26, 26, 27, 26, 25, 28, 27, 25,~
$ fl           <chr> "p", "p", "p", "p", "p", "p", "p", "p", "p", "p~
$ class        <chr> "compact", "compact", "compact", "compact", "co~

What does drv contain?












Facetting






(skipping over a bunch of examples and exercises)



Behind the scenes, geom_bar is creating count to be the y axis.
Lots of other good info in that chapter and the book generally. Check it out!

title: Welcome to Shane's Little Data Science Blog
description:
Welcome to our new blog, Shane's Little Data Science Blog. We hope you enjoy 
reading what we have to say!
contents:
Here is my first blog post. There are many like it, but this one is mine.
There is now a second post.
